subject: Re: [junit] byte can be bigger than 127 ...
msgSnippet: ... the ... and ... Or during the comparison itself: assertTrue( classByte  Byte.MAX_VALUE ); If classByte & Byte.MAX_VALUE are being promoted to ints during
messageBody:
Berin Loritsch wrote:
> Considering the comments in your test, (i.e. Byte and Short violate
the
> expected result, but Integer doesn't) my guess is that for some reason
> your variables are being promoted to integer values durring addition
and
> subtraction.

Or during the comparison itself:

assertTrue( classByte > Byte.MAX_VALUE );

If classByte & Byte.MAX_VALUE are being promoted to ints during this
comparison, it would evaluate to true. This is my best guess, since the
addition is being done with the unary operator ++. So even if an
arithmetic promotion were being done for the addition (which it
shouldn't with ++ or --), the result gets assigned back to the classByte
variable.
